conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process, we need to analyze the area enclosed by the cycle on the \( pV \) diagram.

The work done by the gas during a cyclic process is equal to the area enclosed by the cycle, with the convention that work done by the gas is positive if the cycle is traversed in the counterclockwise direction.
A→B is an isochoric (constant volume) process since the volume remains at 2 L.
B→C is an isobaric (constant pressure) process since the pressure remains at 4 × 10^5 Pa.
C→A is an isochoric (constant volume) process since the volume remains at 5 L.
Since the volume is constant, the work done \( W_{AB} = 0 \).

premise: B→C is isobaric with \( P = 4 \times 10^5 \) Pa and \( \Delta V = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
conclusion: The work done during an isobaric process is \( W_{BC} = 4 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \times 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 = 1200 \, \text{J} \).
Since the volume is constant, the work done \( W_{CA} = 0 \).

premise: Work done in each process: \( W_{AB} = 0 \), \( W_{BC} = 1200 \, \text{J} \), \( W_{CA} = 0 \).
conclusion: The total work done by the gas during the cyclic process is \( W_{\text{total}} = 0 + 1200 \, \text{J} + 0 = 1200 \, \text{J} \).
